title: Aja
dek: Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at Steely Dan—from their early classic rock staples to their latter-day studio sleaze—with new reviews of five of their most influential records.
seoDescription: With 1977’s Aja, Walter Becker and Donald Fagen took their chops and studio finesse to their logical peak, creating a jazz-rock hybrid full of transcendent, indelible songwriting and virtuoso craftsmanship.
promoDescription: Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at Steely Dan—from their early classic rock staples to their latter-day studio sleaze—with new reviews of five of their most influential records.
socialDescription: With 1977’s Aja, Walter Becker and Donald Fagen took their chops and studio finesse to their logical peak, creating a jazz-rock hybrid full of transcendent, indelible songwriting and virtuoso craftsmanship.

title: Gaucho
dek: Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at Steely Dan—from their early classic rock staples to their latter-day studio sleaze—with new reviews of five of their most influential records.
seoDescription: Steely Dan entered the ’80s with something elegant and arid—immaculately conceived malaise-age bachelor-pad music. In these songs, everyone’s alone, or together in a way that’s worse than being alone.
promoDescription: Steely Dan entered the ’80s with something elegant and arid—immaculately conceived malaise-age bachelor-pad music. In these songs, everyone’s alone, or together in a way that’s worse than being alone.

title: The Royal Scam
dek: Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at Steely Dan—from their early classic rock staples to their latter-day studio sleaze—with new reviews of five of their most influential records.
seoDescription: By 1976, Fagen and Becker pushed their music to feel as grotesque as their words. The result is the bleakest and most narratively vivid album of their career, as well as their most misunderstood.
promoDescription: By 1976, Fagen and Becker pushed their music to feel as grotesque as their words. The result is the bleakest and most narratively vivid album of their career, as well as their most misunderstood.
socialDescription: By 1976, Fagen and Becker pushed their music to feel as grotesque as their words. The result is the bleakest and most narratively vivid album of their career, as well as their most misunderstood.

title: Katy Lied
dek: Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at Steely Dan—from their early classic rock staples to their latter-day studio sleaze—with new reviews of five of their most influential records.
seoDescription: Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at Steely Dan—from their early classic rock staples to their latter-day studio sleaze—with new reviews of five of their most influential records.
promoDescription: Steely Dan’s fascinating fourth album, from 1975, lives at the midpoint of the band’s first act. It’s messier, less sure of itself, besotted neither with youthful confidence nor veteran polish.
socialDescription: Steely Dan’s fascinating fourth album, from 1975, lives at the midpoint of the band’s first act. It’s messier, less sure of itself, besotted neither with youthful confidence nor veteran polish.

title: Can’t Buy a Thrill
socialTitle: Steely Dan: Can’t Buy a Thrill
dek: Today on Pitchfork, we are taking a critical look at Steely Dan—from their early classic rock staples to their latter-day studio sleaze—with new reviews of five of their most influential records.
seoDescription: On their debut, Steely Dan brought pop instincts and studied musicianship to rock radio, putting a smooth spin on several hits that would prove to be a Trojan Horse for their esoteric ideas to come.
promoDescription: On their debut, Steely Dan brought pop instincts and studied musicianship to rock radio, putting a smooth spin on several hits that would prove to be a Trojan Horse for their esoteric ideas to come.
socialDescription: On their debut, Steely Dan brought pop instincts and studied musicianship to rock radio, putting a smooth spin on several hits that would prove to be a Trojan Horse for their esoteric ideas to come.

title: Let’s Get Free
dek: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit dead prez’s debut, an iconoclastic rap record built around the politics of liberation.
